DataElement.preferredName: Brain Tumor Computed Tomography Magnetic Resonance Imaging Response Type
DataElement.preferredDefinition: an enumerated list of tumor/disease responses related to the response of a brain tumor from CT (a series of detailed pictures of areas inside the body) or MRI (a procedure in which a magnet linked to a computer is used to create detailed pictures of areas inside the body) scan.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Brain Tumor Computed Tomography Magnetic Resonance Imaging Response
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: information related to the response of a brain tumor from CT (a series of detailed pictures of areas inside the body) or MRI (a procedure in which a magnet linked to a computer is used to create detailed pictures of areas inside the body) scan.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: That part of the central nervous system contained within the cranium, comprising the prosencephalon, mesencephalon, and rhombencephalon. It is derived from the anterior part of the embryonic neural tube. Functions include muscle control and coordination, sensory reception and integration, speech production, memory storage, and the elaboration of thought and emotions.:(NEE-o-PLAY-zha) Abnormal and uncontrolled cell growth.

Concepts.definition: An organ composed of grey and white matter containing billions of neurons that is the center for intelligence and reasoning. It is protected by the bony cranium.

A benign or malignant tissue growth resulting from uncontrolled cell proliferation. Benign neoplastic cells resemble normal cells without exhibiting significant cytologic atypia, while malignant cells exhibit overt signs such as dysplastic features, atypical mitotic figures, necrosis, nuclear pleomorphism, and anaplasia. Representative examples of benign neoplasms include papillomas, cystadenomas, and lipomas; malignant neoplasms include carcinomas, sarcomas, lymphomas, and leukemias.

Property.preferredName: Computed Tomography Magnetic Resonance Imaging Response
Property.preferredDefinition: A method of examining body organs by scanning them with X rays and using a computer to construct a series of cross-sectional scans along a single axis. :Imaging that uses radiofrequency waves and a strong magnetic field rather than x-rays to provide amazingly clear and detailed pictures of internal organs and tissues. The technique is valuable for the diagnosis of many pathologic conditions, including cancer, heart and vascular disease, stroke, and joint and musculoskeletal disorders. :Response; a bodily process occurring due to the effect of some foregoing stimulus or agent.

Concepts.definition: A method of examining structures within the body by scanning them with X rays and using a computer to construct a series of cross-sectional scans along a single axis.

Imaging that uses radiofrequency waves and a strong magnetic field rather than x-rays to provide detailed pictures of internal organs and tissues. The technique is valuable for the diagnosis of many pathologic conditions, including cancer, heart and vascular disease, stroke, and joint and musculoskeletal disorders.
Any act or phenomena, or behavior, constituting a reply or reaction of a living organism or its part to some foregoing stimulus or agent.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: the results or effects (does not include CTC Adverse Events) of therapeutic agents or procedures administered to the patient.

DataElementConcept.origin: NCCTG CRF:North Central Cancer Treatment Group Case Report Form

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: an enumerated list of tumor/disease responses.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The disappearance of all signs of cancer in response to treatment.

Concepts.definition: The disappearance of all signs of cancer in response to treatment.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Diagnostic tests fail to detect presence of disease.

Concepts.definition: Diagnostic tests fail to detect presence of disease.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Cancer that is increasing in scope or severity.

Concepts.definition: A clinical, pathologic, and/or molecular finding indicating that the course of a disease is worsening in terms of extent or severity.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A decrease in the size of a tumor, or in the extent of cancer in the body, in response to treatment.

Concepts.definition: A decrease in the size of a tumor, or in the extent of cancer in the body, in response to treatment.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A decrease in the size of a tumor or in the extent of cancer in the body.

Concepts.definition: Return to a former state; a subsidence of the symptoms of a disease process; in cancer, a decrease in the size of a tumor or in the extent of cancer in the body.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Cancer that is neither decreasing nor increasing in extent or severity.

Concepts.definition: A disease that is neither decreasing nor increasing in extent or severity.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Indicates a task, process or examination that has either not been initiated or not been completed.

Concepts.definition: Indicates a task, process or examination that has either not been initiated or not been completed.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: the response criteria (includes RECIST and others) and associated documentation of disease.

RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: Type; a subdivision of a particular kind of thing.

Concepts.definition: Something distinguishable as an identifiable class based on common qualities.

ValueDomain.origin: NCCTG CRF:North Central Cancer Treatment Group Case Report Form

DataElement.origin: NCCTG CRF:North Central Cancer Treatment Group Case Report Form
